ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Visit name
Race of study subject
ValueRange: American Indian/Alaska Native; Asian; Hawaiian or Pacific Islander; Black or African American; White; More than one race; Unknown or not reported; Other Non-White; Other

ElementDescription: Ethnicity of participant
ValueRange: Hispanic or Latino; Not Hispanic or Latino; Unknown

ElementDescription: Race of Respondent Specify
1.  Psychosis often includes which one of the following symptoms:
Notes: 1= A. Excessive Sleep; 2=B. Feeling hopeless; 3= C. Hearing voices; 4=D. Increased appetite; 5=E. Very high energy

ElementDescription: 2.  One of the main challenges to treating psychosis is:
Notes: 1=A. It is very hard to find a treatment provider; 2=B. People are often too violent to engage in treatment; 3=C. Some people go for long periods of time before starting treatment; 4=The treatment is not usually covered by private insurance; 5=E.  There are no treatments proven to be effective

ElementDescription: 3.  A common symptom of psychosis is:
Notes: 1= A. Being overly happy and having extra; 2=B.Not eating enough and weight loss; 3= C. Sudden attacks of severe anxiety; 4=D. Thinking that others are watching or following; 5=E. Violence; theft; or physical attacks toward others

ElementDescription: 4. The best treatment for the symptoms of psychosis is:
Notes: 1=A. Medicine; 2=B. Relaxation; 3=C. Seclusion; 4=D. Strict diet; 5=E.  Vitamins

ElementDescription: 5.  Which of the following is a common sign of the early stage of psychosis:
Notes: 1=A. Having anger; aggression; and violent attacks;2=B. Having anxiety attacks and nightmares; 3=C. Having problems knowing where you are; 4=D. Overeating and sleeping too much; 5=E. Whispering to yourself and withdrawing from others

ElementDescription: 6. The best arrangement for a 20-year-old with psychosis is:
Notes: 1=A. Half-way house or boarding house with others with psychosis; 2=B. Involuntary treatment in a locked inpatient psychiatric unit; 3=C. Remaining at home and not interacting too much with others; 4= D. Specialty care services that are available in all five boroughs; 5=E. Staying out of stressful situations like school or work

ElementDescription: 7.  A person believes the FBI has put a computer chip in his/her body.  This symptom is called a:
Notes: 1=A.Delusion; 2=B.Hallucination; 3=C. Obsession; 4=D. Phobia; 5=E. Worry

ElementDescription: 8.  People with psychosis usually do better if treatment:
Notes: 1=A. Includes medicine at least twice daily; 2=B. Involves a court order to comply; 3=C.Is involuntary instead of voluntary;4=D. Is provided in a private practice; 5=E.  Is started as soon as possible

ElementDescription: 9.  An inmate who just started experiencing psychosis might be observed to:
Notes: 1=A. Always want attention from others; 2=B. Be among the most aggressive and violent; 3=C.Be quiet; seclusive; and not care about things; 4=D. Be very focused on maintaining personal hygiene; 5=E.Frequently ask for medications

ElementDescription: 10. The best time to start treatment for psychosis is:
Notes: 1=A. Before it starts; 2=B. As soon as symptoms appear; 3=C. Once its clear that symptoms arent going away;4=D.Once the person is in a stable living arrangement; 5=E. After determining how bad symptoms are going to get

ElementDescription: 1.  I am adequately trained to identify inmates who might have psychosis.
Notes: 1=Strongly disagree; 2=Disagree; 3= Agree; 4=Strongly agree

ElementDescription: 2.  Referring inmates who appear to have psychosis to Mental Health can help get them into mental health services after release.
Notes: 1=Strongly disagree; 2=Disagree; 3= Agree; 4=Strongly agree

ElementDescription: 3.  I can describe the symptoms of psychosis.
Notes: 1=Strongly disagree; 2=Disagree; 3= Agree; 4=Strongly agree

ElementDescription: 4.  Specialty mental health services for psychosis after release are available and effective..
Notes: 1=Strongly disagree; 2=Disagree; 3= Agree; 4=Strongly agree

ElementDescription: 5.  I am good at detecting the early symptoms of psychosis.
Notes: 1=Strongly disagree; 2=Disagree; 3= Agree; 4=Strongly agree

ElementDescription: 6.  The Mental Health service here has good connections with outpatient mental health treatment options for inmates after release.
Notes: 1=Strongly disagree; 2=Disagree; 3= Agree; 4=Strongly agree

ElementDescription: 7.  I am good at identifying inmates who need to be referred to Mental Health.
Notes: 1=Strongly disagree; 2=Disagree; 3= Agree; 4=Strongly agree

ElementDescription: 8.  Referring inmates to Mental Health as early as possible increases their chances of getting better.
Notes: 1=Strongly disagree; 2=Disagree; 3= Agree; 4=Strongly agree

ElementDescription: 1.   How confident would you feel interacting with David?
Notes: 1=Not at all confident; 2=Not very confident; 3=Somewhat confident; 4=Very confident

ElementDescription: 2.   How confident would you feel talking to David about possible mental health symptoms?
Notes: 1=Not at all confident; 2=Not very confident; 3=Somewhat confident; 4=Very confident

Notes: 1=Not at all confident; 2=Not very confident; 3=Somewhat confident; 4=Very confident

Notes: 1=Not at all confident; 2=Not very confident; 3=Somewhat confident; 4=Very confident

Notes: 1=Not at all confident; 2=Not very confident; 3=Somewhat confident; 4=Very confident

Notes: 1=Not at all confident; 2=Not very confident; 3=Somewhat confident; 4=Very confident

Notes: 1=Not at all confident; 2=Not very confident; 3=Somewhat confident; 4=Very confident

ElementDescription: 8.  How confident would you feel talking to your supervisor about referring David to Mental Health?
Notes: 1=Not at all confident; 2=Not very confident; 3=Somewhat confident; 4=Very confident

ElementDescription: 10.   How willing would you be to spend an evening socializing with David?
Notes: 1=Very Unwilling; 2=Somewhat Unwilling; 3=Somewhat Willing; 4=Very Willing

Notes: 1=Very Unwilling; 2=Somewhat Unwilling; 3=Somewhat Willing; 4=Very Willing

Notes: 1=Very Unwilling; 2=Somewhat Unwilling; 3=Somewhat Willing; 4=Very Willing

Notes: 1=Very Unwilling; 2=Somewhat Unwilling; 3=Somewhat Willing; 4=Very Willing

ElementDescription: 14.   How willing would you be to stand next to David in a line at the grocery store?
Notes: 1=Very Unwilling; 2=Somewhat Unwilling; 3=Somewhat Willing; 4=Very Willing

ElementDescription: 15.   How willing would you be to have David come into your home to paint a room?
Notes: 1=Very Unwilling; 2=Somewhat Unwilling; 3=Somewhat Willing; 4=Very Willing

ElementDescription: 16.   How willing would you be to give David advice on getting a job within a City agency?
Notes: 1=Very Unwilling; 2=Somewhat Unwilling; 3=Somewhat Willing; 4=Very Willing
